question.text: Which of these statements is not true?

options.text: Crossing over is the exchange of genetic material between two homologous chromosomes.
The enzyme which is involved during crossing over is called recombinase.
Recombination between homologous chromosomes is completed by the end of diakinesis.
Synaptonemal complex is formed during zygotene.

solution.text: The first two stages of prophase I are relatively short-lived compared to the next stage that is pachytene. During this stage bivalent chromosomes now clearly appears as tetrads. This stage is characterised by the appearance of recombination nodules, the sites at which crossing over occurs between non-sister chromatids of the homologous chromosomes. Crossing over is the exchange of genetic material between two homologous chromosomes. Crossing over is also an enzyme-mediated process and the enzyme involved is called recombinase. Crossing over leads to recombination of genetic material on the two chromosomes. Recombination between homologous chromosomes is completed by the end of pachytene, leaving the chromosomes linked at the sites of crossing over.
